results:
Based on the search results, I found information about Polish-Russian literary relations in the 19th century and the reception of Anna Karenina in Poland. Here's what I found:

## Polsko-rosyjskie relacje literackie w XIX wieku i recepcja "Anny Kareniny" w Polsce

The search revealed academic courses at the University of Warsaw specifically focused on Polish-Russian literary relations, examining "dziejów wzajemnych związków literackich polsko-rosyjskich i rosyjsko-polskich" (the history of mutual Polish-Russian and Russian-Polish literary relations).

The academic curriculum includes examination of "Obraz Polaków w twórczości L.Tołstoja" (The image of Poles in L. Tolstoy's work), indicating that Tolstoy's portrayal of Polish characters was a significant aspect of Polish-Russian literary relations.

Research has been conducted on "Klasycy dziewiętnastowiecznej prozy rosyjskiej w Polsce międzywojennej" (Classics of 19th-century Russian prose in interwar Poland), suggesting that Russian literary works, including those by Tolstoy, had a significant presence in Poland.

Regarding Anna Karenina specifically:

The novel "Anna Karenina" was written by Leo Tolstoy between 1873-1877, with its action taking place in the 1860s in tsarist Russia, mainly in Petersburg, Moscow, and surrounding rural estates.

The work is described as "wielka powieść, której problematyka znacznie wykracza poza ramy romansu zamężnej arystokratki i młodego oficera. Książka ta jest bowiem przede wszystkim panoramą epoki i rosyjskiego społeczeństwa" (a great novel whose themes go far beyond the romance of a married aristocrat and young officer. This book is primarily a panorama of the era and Russian society).

Anna Karenina is considered "jedno z najważniejszych dzieł w rosyjskiej literaturze XIX wieku, które wprowadza czytelnika w świat głębokiego realizmu" (one of the most important works in 19th-century Russian literature, which introduces the reader to the world of deep realism).

The search results show that Polish academic institutions have extensively studied Polish-Russian literary connections, with specific focus on how Russian authors like Tolstoy portrayed Polish characters and how Russian literary classics were received in Poland during the interwar period.
